course.subject: CHEM
course.name: General Chemistry I
course.description: This course targets at students who have acquired more advanced knowledge in fundamental Chemistry in high school. Key topics include atomic structure and periodicity, bonding theories, chemical energy, and properties of gases, liquids and solids. Other topics such as chemical kinetics, chemical equilibrium and organic molecules will be briefly reviewed.
course.prerequisites: Level 3 or above in HKDSE 1/2x OR level 3 or above in HKDSE 1x Chemistry OR CHEM 1008 OR CORE 1120

reviews.author: Lkjhgfdsa
reviews.comment_content:
There is no attendance requirement for this course. The exam syllabus is the same as last semesters. Check out other reviews for that. The following are the new concepts this course teaches:

Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Laws – law of definite proportion, law of multiple proportions
Older atomic models – billiard ball model, plum-pudding model, Rutherford model, bohr’s model
Experiments – cathode ray tube experiment, millikan oil droplet experiment

Chapter 2: Atomic Structures and Periodicity

The first part consists of chapters 1 and 2 of DSE E2 physics.

Second part is about quantum atomic model:

Schrodinger’s equation, wave function, atomic orbital, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, quantum numbers, Aufbau principle

The chapter also teaches how to use QM model to account for trends in the periodic table, for instance, why electronegativity is highest at the top right, why atomic size is the largest at the bottom left etc.

Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts

Bond length, definitions of non-polar covalent bonds, polar covalent bonds and ionic bonds, lattice energy, bond energy, lewis structure, resonance structures, formal charge, naming of compounds

Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

VSEPR model, hybridization of orbitals, sigma bonding and pi bonding, molecular orbital model, bond order, paramagnetism

Chapter 5: stoichiometry
(Nothing new here)

Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry

Hydration of ions, strong, weak, non electrolytes, Molarity vs Molality, complete ionic equation, net ionic equation, Brønsted–Lowry definition of acids and bases, non-whole number oxidation numbers, electron donors and acceptors in redox reactions

Chapter 7: Chemical Energy

Heat, work, state function, extensive property, first law of thermodynamics, definition of internal energy, definition of enthalpy, constant-volume calorimetry

Chapter 8: Gases

Pressure, barometer, manometer, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Avogadro’s law, ideal gas law, standard temperature and pressure (STP), Dalton’s law of partial pressures, kinetic molecular theory, effusion and diffusion, real gases behavior, van der Waal’s equation, compressibility

Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

London dispersion forces, polarizability, capillary action, cohesive and adhesive forces, crystalline solids, amorphous solids, unit cell, x-ray diffraction analysis of solids, Bragg equation, atomic solids, metallic solids, network solids, Group 8A solids, molecular solids, ionic solids, hexagonal closest packed (hcp) structure, cubic closest packed (ccp) structure, simple cubic unit cell, body-centered unit cell, face-centered unit cell, net spheres, band model, substitutional alloy, interstitial alloy, doping, p-type semiconductor, n-type semiconductor, p-n junction, holes(semiconductor), octahedral and tetrahedral holes, vapor pressure, enthalpy of vaporization, enthalpy of fusion, definitions of melting and boiling, normal melting and boiling points, supercooling and superheating, phase diagram

----------

The above are primarily from the textbook, Chemistry: An Atoms First Approach, 2nd ed. which the course uses.

And I probably haven't included things from the lecture notes, Professor Li's lecture notes are so full of content, which deterred me from reading them.

----------

As you can see there is a lot to learn in this course, some of the concepts are not discussed too in depth. For example, I still have no idea how orbitals actually hybridize. Nonetheless, this serves as a decent introductory course.

----------

There is a post on the University of Houston subreddit where you can find the download link of the textbook in the comments. Just search 'An atoms first approach 2nd edition' there.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended three lectures. I never asked the TA any questions. So I apologize for not being able to give a grade that reflects accurately the teaching quality.

What I remember is that Professor Li had a very heavy accent.

And they also recommend doing some pre-study before attending the lectures, which I think is not humanly possible because there is too much to digest. Just learn at your own pace.

In case you need them, recordings of lectures are uploaded after a few days to possibly a week. Lecture notes are uploaded only after the professor has finished teaching the chapter.

You can find the lecture notes, answer keys to textbook questions and some past papers here: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1QoAhy0lvGzuIj1waii6w3XCyfiIsj6Nc?usp=sharing

Although you need not attend/ watch the lecture videos, I do recommend attending/ watching the tutorial sessions held before each of the exam. The questions demonstrated are similar to those in the exams.

highest 98

Grade A+

How to get a good grade:

Read the textbook.

Try your best to finish all the questions they recommend in the powerpoint slides, since around 10 of the questions will appear in the mid-term, and 10 other will appear in final exam. What's even better is that the answers to those questions are exactly the same in the exams as well, they don't change the numerical values even if it's a calculation problem.

Revise the notes only if you have time and want to get a really good grade, the exams are based on the content of textbook. (I didn't do that except for the first chapter, still enough for an A+)

And if, for some reason, you still have time left. I suggest reviewing subtle concepts that you don't normally think will be asked, e.g. formal charge(in the ppt they said it's optional to learn), the definition of atomic mass unit, formula mass and molar mass, definition of acids and bases, determination of direction of work done from a chemical equation, factors affecting vapor pressure (the textbook does not mention what factors won't affect it). To my surprise, the concepts I listed above were asked in mid-term and final.

If you can't follow the professors' teachings, don't even bother attending/ watching the lectures. But attending/ watching tutorial sessions held before each of the exam is highly recommended, because the questions they teach there are similar to those in the exams.
reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.comment_teaching:
As mentioned, the most significant thing that he taught me is the importance of skipping lectures. His Lectures are very boring and he always speaks softly when he is saying anything important.

I attend most of the lectures before the midterm, however, I got really low marks for that.  While after the midterm, I skipped most of the lectures and study by myself, the result is much better than the midterm.

Don't waste your time to attend lectures of this instructor.

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Ok la...
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term:
Classification of matter, Elements and Periodic table, Measurements and significant figures, atoms, ions, molecules, compounds, Atomic spectra and the Bohr model, Quantum mechanical model(Wave-particle duality, Quantum numbers, energy and shapes of atomic orbitals, polyelectronic atoms), Periodic trends in atomic properties, Ionic bonding, Covalent bonding, Lewis Structures(Resonance, Formal Charges), VSEPR

After mid-term:
Valence Bond Theory and hybridization, Molecular Orbital Theory, Chemical stiochiometry, Reactions in aqueous solutions(Properties, precipitation, acid-base, redox), Chemical energy(1st law of thermodynamics, enthalpy, Hess' Law), Gases(Properties, gas laws, Kinetic Molecular Theory, Ideal and real gases)

More than half of the course are used to teach Bohr model, Quantum mechanical model, Lewis Structures, VSEPR Theory, Valence Bond Theory and Molecular Orbital Theory. They are the most important content in this course(and in Chemistry).
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Jia's English is significantly poorer than other professors, but the accent is still understandable. He mostly read from ppt slides directly, without much elaboration. There are good examples, exercise and 'review questions' in the ppts, but he didn't spend a lot of time to explain the questions and the answers. He is willing to answer student's questions, but he frequently shift between speaking English and Mandarin when answering questions, so we can't get his answer really well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
10% Assignments 40% Mid-term exam 50% Final exam
Grading is fair.
Mid-term: 71.5/90 (Mean: 51.1, SD: 15.2, +1.34SD)
Final: 79.5/100 (Mean: 61.5, SD: 14.2, +1.27SD)
Homework 1: 49/50 (Mean: 44.1)
Homework 2: 39.5/50 (Mean: 44.3)
Total: 80.38/100 -->A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
Assignments: 2 compulsory homework in the whole semester, each consists of 4 pages of worksheets, usually given 1 week before submission deadline. If you have source(though I don't have) you will carry this part in less than an hour, if you don't have you need to spend at most 2 hours on it.
No attendance required, lecture videos are uploaded on Canvas.(Only about 40-65% students attend the lectures each time)
Mid-term Exam: 67% MCs and 33% SQs. Some MCs are tricky, but if you revised enough it's not hard to get most of them correct. If your concepts are clear enough you should get SQs all right.
Final exam: 58% MCs and 42% SQs. MCs are signficantly more tricky, especially those related to energy and gas. If your concepts are clear enough you should get SQs all right.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I feel Prof Lu reads the ppt most of the time so I don't really like his teaching style. But his ppt covered the details you need.
Prof Huang's teaching is more interesting in comparison (maybe this is also because the content she covered was more concrete). Her lectures often start with a small experiment demonstration as an inspiration to let us think about why what we saw in the experiment happened. The content of that lecture will regard the experiment and she will conclude what we learn in that lecture by explaining the experiment result. This kind of teaching mode makes the course a little more interesting.

Btw I think the textbook isn't really necessary to buy. If you just want to pass the course and do well on the exams, just go borrow the book from the library or find one on a bookshelf in hall and do the exercises. Attending the lectures or watching the video and then review the ppt is enough for this course. I bought the textbook but I seldom use it so I kind of found that it's wasting money to buy it...

It is abstract, (Wave function, molecular orbital), which you might have completely no

Haipeng Lu for content before midterm and

There is one mysterious problem, no one know why

the one that teaches good (Jinqing Huang) , teaches the easiest content (HKDSE stuff).

While the one that teaches poor (Haipeng Lu) , teaches the hardest content (Quantum theory).

It is already abstract to understand Quantum theory,

not to mention how poor Haipeng Lu taught make thing even unclear,

I suggest you to read book yourself, it is more efficient than listening to him.

Meanwhile, Jinging Huang made experiments very often,

and the things she taught is very clear,

even I think everyone already know the content if they are from HKDSE.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof LI was the instructor of the lectures before midterm exam. You could tell that he is very passionate about teaching chemistry from his loud voice which often hard to listen to what he was speaking and he could not make the class stop talking so it is often difficult to focus.

It is fun to have Prof HUANG as the instructor for the lectures after midterm exam as she performs experiments that are related to the knowledge she will be teaching in every lecture. There were also some mcq provided by her for us to do in the lecture and she will explain the answers so it is quite easy to catch up with her teaching.

Tutorial sessions were held before midterm exam and final exam which were helpful as the questions involved in the sessions were similar to those in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was acceptable for me.
Midterm exam and final exam each takes up 50% of the final grading.

Midterm exam:
average score: 39.9/60
standard deviation: 9.8
Final exam:
average score: 33.6/50
standard deviation: 8.4

My score was 47/60 for midterm exam and 46/50 for final exam and my grade is A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was acceptable. It was not hard to get an A or B for this course if you read the textbook and do the homework questions, skipping the lectures is not recommended but it's ok to skip them once a while. The exam questions are often easier than those in the textbook so if you managed to handle the hw questions well, the exam will not be hard for you.

All questions in exams are MC in this semester due to the switch to online mode. Both exams consist of 50 MCs.
reviews.comment_teaching: The ppts are well-designed, they cover all content that will appear in exams. Professor Jia uploaded ppts to Canvas prior to the lecture, while Professor Li did that after the lecture. Professor Jia's English accent is quite poor, you may need some time to figure out what he is trying to speak. Professor Li has a much better English accent. Both professors are willing to answer students' questions, you can raise your question at the end of lecture. To conclude, I would give an A- and A to Professor Jia and Li respectively (the '-' is due to Professor Jia's poorer English accent, I spent a considerable amount of time to fully understand his words).
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 50%
Final: 50%

The grading is good, but you still need to study hard if you really want an A range. The mean grade is B-, which is reasonable. Below shows the statistics of this semester.

Midterm
Mean: 66.35/100
SD: 14.68
Highest: 98/100
My score: 92/100

Final
Mean: 63.06/100
SD: 14.06
Highest: 98/100
My score: 94/100

My final grade is A+, fair enough. A score of +1sd would likely give you an A-. If you want to get an A or A+ you should aim for a score of +1.5sd.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. You do not need to hand in any homework. However, I strongly recommend you to finish the suggested questions since 20% of them will reappear in exams. They also enable you to understand the course materials better.

Moreover, if you want to secure a good grade I suggest reading the textbook (hardcopy or electronic version are both fine) instead of merely looking at ppts. I skipped some lectures (coz I am lazy) and started revising the textbook several days before exams. Still, I managed to obtain a satisfactory grade. Also, it is not a must to purchase the latest version of textbook (3rd edition) as you can find a majority of homework questions appearing in the older version (2nd edition). The main content of textbook does not have any change. I only read the 2nd edition.

reviews.author: Midnite
reviews.comment_content: The course covers almost all parts of chemistry in high school. Roughly from the first year to the second year. Containing basic chemistry theory such as Dalton, Rutherford, etc. Stochiometry, Gas, molecule structure. The content feels much more advanced and deep than that of high school with more explanation on most theories and their origin, giving a better picture of chemistry itself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall they divide the teaching to two sections, first half to Mr. JIA, Guocheng an the second half to Ms. Huang, Jinqing. They both explain the course quite clearly and detailed along with powerpoints. Though they did not just read off the slides, but you can get most of the lectures from just reading it. Mr. Jia's English tend to be harder to hear, but still good enough.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is divided to midterm and final exam. Both have 50 multiple questions exam and is proctored through zoom. The exam covers all the materials in the slides and mostly from the last tutorial given. There's rarely any questions from last year exam.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework at all, just follow the lectures and do well in the exam.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Every lecture is like a "talk-show" and demonstrate lots of key concepts
reviews.comment_content:
Mid-term:
Chemical Foundations
Atomic Structure and Orbitals
Bonding
Molecular Orbitals and Hybridization

These are the difficult chapters of this course and you should spend a lot of time to get familiar with the concepts and calculations. These chapters are like atomic physics and DSE students are new to these topics since these were included in the old A Level syllabus. Please read the lecture notes in detail and work on the examples.

Final:
Stoichiometry
Chemical Reactions
Energy
Gases
Liquids and Solids

The first few chapters are easy since they are entirely the same as DSE. However, please get familiar with the First Law of Thermodynamics, Gas Laws, KMT which are supposed to be new for students without Physics Background.

The last chapter is difficult in some of the parts, the calculations of solids require in-depth understanding of each cubic structure.

Key to secure grade:
read textbook
read the slides
work on exercises
attend lectures and listen to talk show
make some notes
work on tutorial and review questions
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am so sure that you will be amused by Xiaoyuan teaching. He is the Chair Professor of the Chemistry Department and he has a long teaching experience.

He prepares well for all lectures and able to deliver the key concepts of each chapter with in-depth explanation and the use of graphics and animations. The lecture PPTs include the details of each chapter and give supplement to the content which are not mentioned in the textbook. The lecture PPTs are designed with proper and rational logic, which are easy to follow and understand. The lecture PPTs assist the Professor to point out the fundamental concepts of each session of every single chapter.

The presentation skills of Xiaoyuan, I would say it's funny and causes lots of laughter. He has a special voice and speaks loud during lectures. He behaves like a proactive child and presents the content with fluctuations and intonations. As a Mainland Professor, his English is much better than those local professors and easy to understand. Sometimes he makes good use of his voice to grab students' attention.

Some of his pronunciation are quite funny indeed :) Enjoy lectures and you definitely get lots of rewards. Feel free to raise questions through email or just face-to-face.

Xiaoyuan also prepares review and tutorial sessions before exams, showing that he is helpful and responsible.

By the way, Xiaoyuan is energetic:) Really a good professor and teacher in my first semester study in the University.

For TA Elaine, she particularly worked on the tutorial session before exams, working on examples of exam-oriented questions. Better not to miss her tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is actually fair and reasonable for a 3-crd course.

But be aware of the traps of questions which may appear in the examinations, key concepts and definitions are examined.

If you score above mean, a B grade or above is not a difficult task. But if you score high in mid-term(which is much more difficult than final) and get a reasonable score in final, A range should not be a problem.

Grade: B+ (I did slightly above mean in midterm but over 1 SD in final, so it's standard curve-shape grading, you know the grading for most Year 1 Courses are very strict compared to those major courses)
reviews.comment_workload:
Actually the workload is reasonable.

Just read and understand the details of the lecture slides and the textbook examples. Try to apply the concepts learnt by doing the self-practice provided in the textbook and read the sample answers to grab the required concepts. Please do the self-practice provided during the tutorial sessions since some of the questions are similar to those appear in the examinations.

However, to secure your grade, hardwork is still need. Students experience difficulties when they studied the first few chapters of the course. Try to understand and memorize the concepts and logic, make some key notes and work on the exercises for further consolidation.

reviews.author: Small__Potato
reviews.title: interesting course with good lecturers
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter Review: Measurement and Calculations in Chemistry
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2*: Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3: Bonding - General Concepts
Chapter 4:* Molecular Structure and Orbitals

Unlike the other semesters, we only studied ch1 to ch4 in this summer semester. Also, there were only 13 students enrolled so the lecturers welcome students to ask questions and have some interaction. This course started the first lesson in july, so there may not have enough time to teach to the all the topic, thus the content is much fewer. Among these chapters, Chapter Review are the basic common sense about math and science taught in junior secondary school. Chapter 1 are some history of Atomic model which was learned in compulsory part of dse physics. Chapter 2 introduced the atom (wave particles duality, Atomic orbitals, electron spin etc.) which partly learned in elective part of dse physics. Chapter 3 and 4 are new things about bonding ( VSEPR, Lewis structure, hybridization and molecular orbitals). Overall, these topics are mainly related to high school physics but not chemistry ( but it is still a chemistry course without any Chemical equation)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Emily
Emily was only responsible for teaching chapter review to chapter 2. Her teaching style is similar to the normal high school teacher. She prepared a detailed ppt with highlighted important points so it was very easy to revise.

Jason
Jason was responsible for teaching ch3 and 4. His teaching style was compatible to private tutorial school teacher. He printed some self made colored lecture notes for us and then wrote some notes on it. We then copied the notes, but the annotated notes usually release on canvas after a few days. He will bring some apparatus to the classroom and do experiment, although only for once throughout the whole. Also he was nice to ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good.
two quiz and one midterm and one final
quiz can be done on canvas with 15 mc questions, one and a half hour time limit.
the second quiz is more difficult than the first one. The midterm responded by Emily was all mc and very easy. But the final by Jason was all long questions with small parts and it was quite challenging. there are time limit for midterm and final but all of students can finish them on time.
I got 5* in both dse physics and chemistry and I got an A in CHEM 1020.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not a big issue. Since the midterm is very easy, and the content are learned in high school, you can simply read the ppt and understand them without recitation. But for the final, you are better pay some effort on it.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
Taught by Prof. Halpert (before midterm)
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2: Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts
Chapter 4: Molecular Geometry and Bonding Theories

Taught by Prof. Huang (after midterm)

Chapter 7:Thermochemistry
Chapter 8:Gases
Chapter 9:Liquids&Solids(not tested)

*There is one tutorial class respectively near the midterm and the final exam.

*Materials taught before midterm would NOT be tested in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Halpert's teaching is already good enough. Although the topics he taught were basically boring theories and equations, his intonation did helped a lot in attempt to prevent us from falling asleep.

Dr. Huang is a cute professor (in the way of speaking style) in spite of her accent. A number of experiments were performed during class, so those lectures were really interesting.

Miss Lee, Tsz Kiu is the IA of the course teaching in the tutorial classes. She is responsive and patient in answering questions about lectures in email. It would be greater if you ask her face to face for more detailed explanation.
reviews.comment_grading:
You may refer to the attached file if you wish for details and data.

It is suggested you take a good review on materials for midterm despite its percentage accounted in the final score. Those materials in the midterm are mainly theories, which are new to DSE students, whereas those in the final are entirely DSE stuffs. Therefore, it could really help if you can get a high mark in midterm.

Also, it is reminded that tutorial class can ONLY help you get a satisfactory score. Reviewing all lecture slides is a must for those aiming A. Details of complex formulae excluded from the tutorial slides can be ignored, but their variables and the uncertainty inequality should be recited as it was tested.

One hint for the midterm exam is that always think more and deeper using the basic theory. Examples used in class to illustrate the theory are chosen to be simple, but questions are usually one level higher in difficulty.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload. Only 2 assignments, one before midterm and one before final.

Mistakes in assignments do not significantly affect the grade as each assignment only accounts for 5% of the total score. Instead, make sure you can get a high score in the midterm exam as the mean of final exam is quite high and it may be impossible for you to get a huge improvement in the total score.

reviews.comment_teaching:
This is the first time that the two instructors have taught this course. I don't think they have arranged the course outline well.
Prof. Halpert(before midterm) is a native English speaker. But I have to say that his teaching didn't make too much sense. He just read out his lecture notes hurriedly without explaining the concepts clearly. Furthermore, there were hardly any exercise questions in his lecture notes, making it difficult for you to prepare for the midterm exam.
Most of Prof. Huang's part(after midterm) was covered in the high school. There were adequate amount of examples and exercise in her lecture notes for you to understand the concepts. But since the content of the second half was so straightforward, I couldn't concentrate in her lectures so that I almost skipped all the lectures after midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
scheme: two assignments, each 5%
midterm 40% final 50%
Since Prof. Halpert's teaching was not effective, the midterm was difficult since I didn't fully understand the concepts. But what I couldn't understand is that some of the questions in the midterm were not covered in the lecture notes or promised not to appear in the exam.
Also, since the final exam was non-cumulative and the content of the second half was so straightforward, you can hardly get a huge advantage over others even if you pay efforts. The final is almost senseless and what determines your final grade is just your midterm......
my grade:
assignment 1 59.5/60 assignment 2 40/40
midterm 72.5/90 above mean 1.6SD
final 94/100 above mean 1.5SD
final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Just two assignments, one before midterm and one before final. I think reviewing the lecture notes thoroughly and fully understand the concepts before the exams is enough for a good grade. Do pay attention to the midterm!

reviews.author: kDavidL
reviews.comment_content:
CHEM 1020 covers 9 chapters (Ch. 1-9) from the textbook Chemistry An Atoms First Approach. The chapters can be grouped into 4 topics:

Ch. 1-2 focus on atoms, namely, the structure of an atom. The concept of atomic orbital will be introduced. The idea of quantum mechanics as a perspective on the Periodic Table of Elements.

Ch. 3-4 focus on bondings, namely, the ionic and covalent bondings. These bondings will be viewed and discussed from the atomic orbital perspective.

Ch. 5-7 focus on chemical reactions. Students will "learn" about chemical reactions from the perspectives of energy, mass, and type. ("learn" cus you've learned them in HKDSE NSS Chemistry)

Ch. 8-9 focus on the state of matter. Students will study molecules and atoms in gas, liquid and solid phases. Part of HKDSE NSS Physics content will be covered, namely the part related to ideal gas.

Most of the students will find the first 4 chapters difficult. It's thus highly recommended to find online resources to aid your study in these chapters. (cus you're not the only one that finds atomic orbital difficult to understand)
reviews.comment_teaching: Both instructors show their passion for both Chemistry and teaching. They do emphasize class order and conduct, especially regarding the noisiness (i.e. No talking/ Talk with a low voice). Prof. HUANG starts her lectures with demonstrations which students may be invited to assist her while Prof. LI starts his lectures right off with the lecture contents. (No demonstration cus, well, there aren't many experiments or demonstrations related to the atomic structure that can be done in a lecture theatre) One thing to note about the instructors is that you may need to use PowerPoint to aid your understanding of the instructors' delivery. (i.e. accents)
reviews.comment_grading: Grading of CHEM 1020 depends solely on exams, i.e. the mid-term exam (50%) and the final exam (50%). For each exam, 20% of the questions are randomly selected from the homework listed.
reviews.comment_workload: No compulsory assignments, but the instructors highly recommend doing the suggested questions in the textbook. Instructors will list out the questions on the ppt of the first lecture of each chapter. (Except for Prof. HUANG who somehow thinks it's a good idea to list the questions together with the answers) The answers are uploaded as soon as the last lecture of the chapter is ended.

reviews.author: Candy626
reviews.title: Fun course
reviews.comment_content:
Contents:
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2: Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3: Bonding - General Concepts
Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals
------------------------------Mid term------------------------------
Chapter 5: Stoichiometry
Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions &
Solution Stoichiometry
Chapter 7: Chemical Energy
Chapter 8: Gases
Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids
--------------------------------Final--------------------------------
Note that the final does not examine anything taught before the mid term.
Both professors includes extra stuff in their lecture ppts, so make sure you study his ppts besides just the textbook.

Contents before the mid term (i.e. atomic and molecular orbitals etc.) are a bit abstract and hard, and you may need sometime to figure out what is happening. But I find the topics very interesting.
Contents after the mid term are mostly things you learn in DSE Chemistry and Physics, besides Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids. It is relatively easier to understand the contents.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructors are Professor Li and Professor Huang.
The TA is Dr. Ng, Tsz Kin.

There are 2 80 minutes lectures per week.
There will be extra mid term and final review sessions.
Attendence is not taken for both lectures and review sessions.
Note that I attended all lectures before the mid term but only a few lectures after the mid term.

C for Professsor Li.
He voice is loud and tone is very energetic.
His English is good but has quite heavy accent.
He uses his lecture ppts and points at the ppt using a laser pointer.
He seldom tells jokes though, but it is ok since he is so energetic.
Overall very lively, I can feel that he want to teach us a lot of things.
However, his lecture ppts are so full of content, such that it starts to look like a textbook.
He also overcomplicate things, and often make things sound much more complicated than they should.

A for Professor Huang.
Her voice is loud and high pitched, and tone is lively, but a bit too sharp.
Her English is good but accent is also quite heavy (much more audible than Professor Li's).
Her lecture slides are much more reasonable, and actually seems like slides.
She includes a bunch of practice questions in her slides, and asks us to answer in lectures.
She also explain stuff more clearly than Professor Li.
Does fun experiments in lecture (she sometimes even ask students to participate in the experiments).
Sadly I did not attend many of her lessons.
Professor Huang is kinda cute btw.

A for Dr. Ng, Tsz Kin.
Kind and friendly TA.
Good English and good accent.
Voice is reasonabley loud and tone is friendly.
I did not ask him many questions, but he replies quickly and doesn't mind answering bunch of them.
I once saw him discuss with students for 1.5h after a lecture (note that our lectures ends at 6pm).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is not released so cannot really comment.
Probably uses absolute grading.

Grading scheme:
Mid-term Exam (50%)
Final Exam (50%)
In each Exam, ~ 20% Problems/Questions are randomly selected from HW

Midterm mean is at 39.93/60.
Final mean is at 33.49/50.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very light.

The professors asked us to read through the textbook before they teach the chapter, and give out homework for every chapter.
Homework contains all the odd number questions in the textbook.
However, since both are ungraded, you can skip both reading assignment and homework.

Took me about 2 to 3 days to study before both mid term and final. May take longer if you are not familiar with atomic and molecular orbitals, or did not study DSE Physics.

reviews.author: David Zheglov
reviews.comment_content:
The content is consistent with a book “Chemistry. An Atoms first approach”, 3rd edition by Zumdahl. If you took Chemistry in your high school, it should not be hard for you.

Second part: Chapters 5-9

However, in second part you can watch and participate in real experiments, which professor shows to audience.

Professor HUANG, Jinqing strictly follows the curriculum, shows real experiments. She is doing her best in explaining all concepts.
Overall, they are both excellent teachers.
reviews.comment_grading:

50% Final (content of 5-9 Chapters)

For many students the first 4 chapters are a litthe harder than the chapter 5-9. For mainland students, it could be easier because they learn a lot in high school.

50% midterm+50% final term.
For me, midterm 58/60  mean 39.9   final 49/50  mean 33.57  A+

reviews.author: APKB
reviews.title: Better to have both Physics and Chemistry basics before enrolling this course.
reviews.comment_content:
In part 1, many topics are related to Physics but not much about Chemistry; in part 2, it is finally Chemistry but mixed with a little bit Physics.

Part 1
1. Chemical Foundations
2. Atomic Structure and Periodicity
3. Bonding - General Concepts
4. Molecular Structures and Orbitals

Part 2
5. Stoichiometry
6. Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry
7. Chemical Energy
8. Gases
9. Liquids and Solids
reviews.comment_teaching:
There are two professors teaching in this course, Prof Li and Prof Huang. Prof Li deserves an "F" in teaching while Prof Huang deserves an "A", so average is a "C-".

Prof Li only upload the materials after lectures including his PowerESSAY. All of us have no idea of whether to jot notes or wait for PPT, so I chose to wait for video recording so that I can refer to PPT and try to follow him. His PPT matches all the bad examples of presentation slides, e.g., using crazy colors and backgrounds, 30 words for one point, etc. He just read aloud words by words and does not explain the proper nouns at all. I have no DSE Physics background and easily get lost during lectures. There are ZERO interactions between students and himself so everyone in the lecture theatre is just doing their own stuffs, no experiments, no in-class polls, etc. What's even worse is he only focus on those complicated content out of textbooks, with no practice questions in-class and assume we all understand the basics stuff including those Physics. Also, his English accent is terrible, but you can still bearly get what he means.

Prof Huang prepares a series of funny experiments during lectures and many in-class poll to let us know we understand the content or not. She explains very clearly if we are in trouble, also welcome us to ask her questions after class, not just ask us to contact the TA. Her English accent and tone is very clear and cute. What's even surprised me is that she knows Cantonese! She is passionate on interacting with students and used a lot of daily life examples and experiments, even hand-make some models to illustrate some complicated concepts! She is one of the best professors in HKUST in my opinion. However,
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite fair. All exams are MCQs only, non-cummulative.
Midterm exam (50%) + Final exam (50%)

~My score~
Midterm: 52/60 (mean 39.9/60, SD 9.8)
Final: 46/50 (mean 33.6/50, SD 8.4)
Overall: 89.33% (A)
[fyi, 2022 DSE Chem Lv5, w/o Physics]
reviews.comment_workload: Only a midterm exam and a final exam, no compulsory assignments nor quizzes. You only need to try some in-book exercises and do some revision on book before exam as part of the questions will appear in the exam. Or, past papers?

reviews.author: hardplastic
reviews.comment_content: Mostly DSE Physics and Chemistry, with a little bit extra things like Orbital, Lattice Structure, etc.. Difficulty of calculation is similar to DSE, if you do good in both DSE Phy and Chem, you don't need to put a large effort on this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Li's accent is totally a mess. You won't understand what he is speaking if you are not very good at English. And his powerpoint is like his accent, a disaster. He just writes out everything explicitly and highlights everything. The meaning of powerpoint, which is to briefly introduce ideas, is completely lost.

Prof. Huang's accent is much better than Prof. Li's, although still with some mandarin accent, but you can understand it easily. She demonstrates many experiment in lecture which actually makes the lecture quite fun.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm and final are both contribute 50% to the total score.
Things appeared in midterm will not appear again in final so that's fair to have such a grading scheme.

Midterm mean: 39.9/60, SD: 9.8, my score: 58/60
Final mean: 33.6/50, SD: 8.4, my score: 49/50

Overall grade: A+

Slightly more than 1 SD above mean can get an A according to my friend, so I think the grade is very good.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework is optional, so exams are the only workload.

reviews.author: Fructose
reviews.title: Learn by ppt and get a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
————For Midterm
Chapter 1 | Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2 | Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3 | Bonding
Chapter 4 | Molecular Structure and Orbitals
————For Final
Chapter 5 | Chemical Stoichiometry
Chapter 6 | Chemical Reactions in Aqueous Solution
Chapter 7 | Chemical energy: Thermochemistry
Chapter 8 | Gases
Chapter 9 | Liquids & Solids

    Although I haven't learned most of the content before, it seems not difficult to acquire most of the concepts. The concepts are not difficult, but indeed large in quantity, so it may be a good choice to take notes for every concept.
    I have never attended class after the first two, but I think it's enough to get a good grade get the homework done and view every ppt carefully.
    The most difficult part for me would be the Atomic Structure models as I haven't learned structural chemistry before, so I have to read the book thoroughly myself. But the book was easy to understand with a clear structure, so although it indeed takes a period of time, I think it's worth doing so.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Li has a mainland accent, and it would be difficult to identify each word he was saying with masks.
    Prof Huang's English is fluent although I have only watched a bit of recording of the class.
    The reason I grade teaching as B is mostly because both of them have PPT with really clear structures, so although I have attend few classes, I still managed to learn most of the knowledge through PPT and make notes that was easy to remember.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was good for me taking it as a Common Core Course. It's 50% midterm and 50% final, both non-openbook exams. Since the midterm and final include different parts, it's totally OK for me to forget all the instant after the exam: )
    All of the exam are multiple choice questions, and it's highly recommended to visit past-paper and listen to the tutorial for each exam. Some high difficulty questions are similar.
    grades:
    Midterm 57/60, with mean 39.9.
    Final 47/50, with mean 33.6.
    Got an A+ in the end.
    That's a satisfying grade as I only take it as a CCC.
reviews.comment_workload:
For Prof Li who taught the part before midterm, I would like to say the workload is a disaster. He requires us to FINISH ALL THE QUESTIONS ON THE BOOK and 20% of them will be in the exam. That's a mountain load, dude...
   But Prof Huang has selected some exercises as homework. That's really considerate and easy to done.

reviews.author: whaddayamean
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: gab
reviews.title: Should work hard for good grade
reviews.comment_content:
There are 9 chapters, namely:

Chemical Foundations;
Atomic Structures and Periodicity;
Bonding: General Concepts;
Molecular Structure and Orbitals;

Stoichiometry;
Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry;
Chemical Energy;
Gases, and;
Liquids and Solids

Chapters 1-4 are taught before the midterm, and 5-9 and after the midterm.

The content is not very difficult, but it's easy to get lost or confused if you don't attend lectures or read up. For all the DSE people, the content before midterm is almost entirely new, the stuff after midterm is more familiar, but introduces a couple new concepts
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professors are good at explaining, and are helpful if asked questions. Although, Professor Jia's accent is sometimes quite heavy, so make sure to ask if you don't understand something.

All lectures are recorded and uploaded to canvas, and "completed" lecture notes are only uploaded after the lectures ("Completed" because lecture notes with many blanks are uploaded before lectures because they want us to fill in the blanks during the lectures).
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance is not required, but I highly suggest attending or watching lecture videos if you don't know much about the content (or if you're like me and learn better with someone explaining)

The grading scheme is split between midterm and final, with both of them being worth 50% of the course grade. As omicron made its grand debut during this semester, the exam was open internet, so the mean this time was higher than previous semesters.

Statistics:

Midterm (50%)  All MC
Mean 70
SD 16.35
Highest 100
Lowest 28
My score 94

Final (50%) All MC
Mean 78
SD 12
Highest 100
Lowest 40
My score 92

In the end, I achieved an A
reviews.comment_workload: There are no compulsory assignments or tutorials, so not counting studying for the exams, this course has basically 0 workload. However, the professor recommends some practice problems from the book for each chapter, if you want a really good grade, you can do the problems, however, studying the concepts should suffice.

reviews.comment_content:
Content was relatively like Physics instead of Chemistry. For a person who has not taken any physics apart from the boderline useless PHYS 1001, it took me more effort to learn about certain topics.

Chapter 1.  Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2.   Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3.   Bonding: General Concepts
Chapter 4.   Molecular structure and orbitals
Chapter 5.  Chemical Stoichiometry
Chapter 6.  Chemical reactions in aqueous solution
Chapter 7.  Thermochemistry: Chemical Energy
Chapter 8.  Gases
Chapter 9.  Liquids and solids

Midterm covers chapters 1 to 4, and finals chapter 5 to 9.

Chapters 3 and 4 were the most difficult parts for midterms. The concept of atomic orbitals may be new to non-Atomic World HKDSE students. Coupled with Jia's accent, the difficulty of the midterm is higher than that of the midterm.

Chapters 5, 6, 7 are revisions of HKDSE bonding, redox, and enthalpy, and are not particularly difficult.

Chapter 8 is about gases, and DSE Physics students can see familiar content such as PV = nRT.

Chapter 9 is the most difficult chapter in the final. Solids and how they pack together are rather difficult to visualize. Unit cells are an important concept to grasp.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The content before the midterm is taught by Prof Jia, and the content after that is taught by Prof Jinqing.

Prof. Jia had a rather strong accent, and that does hinder understanding of the students. To me, his accent often seems "drunk", but the delivery of his concepts are often acceptably clear. Do be prepared to self-study a bit more for Jia's part though.

Prof. Jinqing's accent was relatively more clear, and her explanations are clear as well. She does small experiments throughout the semester, which makes the otherwise monotonous lecturing more bearable.

Both profs provide polling questions to clear often confusing concepts, which is a definite plus. The questions can also be used to revise for the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is rather likely that this course follows absolute grading, and each subgrade is in 5% intervals.

That means, 95% overall for A+, 90% for A, and so on.

Grading is determined by a 50% midterm and 50% final only.

Got a B+ for 82%.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is low in general. A course without assignments meant that there isn't much to do except revise for the midterm and the final.

Past papers help in revising quite a lot, as they provide insight into the format of the exams. Do get some if you can.

reviews.comment_teaching:
JIA has a very strong accent, so some may dislike having him as a professor. However, he is definitely passionate in teaching, and is willing to answer any questions you will have with a good explanation. His teaching was quite fun, and I don't regret having him as a professor.

JIA will ask questions and do polling to help you with your understanding of the course. The polling doesn't affect your grades in any way (nor are they compulsory), so feel free to choose the wrong answers.

LI has a better accent, but his way of talking is quite interesting. Again, he is definitely passionate in teaching, and was quite fun as a professor. I don't regret having him as a professor either.

The TA, Elaine Wong, is very helpful. She speaks fluent English and Cantonese. She will answer any questions instantly through Zoom chat. You can't go wrong with having her as your TA.
reviews.comment_grading:
I obtained an A in this course, both my mid-term score and final score around 80%.
Note that due to COVID, this semester was fully online, so results may vary.

The weighting was mainly focused on the mid-term and final.

Background:
I obtained an easy 5 in both DSE Chemistry and Physics, didn't study, didn't attend the later half of the lectures, and didn't do the homework.
You can use my background to determine the level of difficulty of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload.

There is no compulsory homework which you have to do. Of course, they provide some supplementary questions (with answers) for self revision.

You also don't have to do much of revision. Simply attending the lectures and legitimately focusing on the course will help you a long way with your grades.

reviews.author: 日修運動服愛好者
reviews.title: Better rely on Elaine rather than the mainland professors
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Laws – law of definite proportion, law of multiple proportions
Older atomic models – billiard ball model, plum-pudding model, Rutherford model, bohr’s model
Experiments – cathode ray tube experiment, millikan oil droplet experiment

Chapter 2: Atomic Structures and Periodicity

The first part consists of chapters 1 and 2 of DSE E2 physics.

Second part is about quantum atomic model:

Schrodinger’s equation, wave function, atomic orbital, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, quantum numbers, Aufbau principle

The chapter also teaches how to use QM model to account for trends in the periodic table, for instance, why electronegativity is highest at the top right, why atomic size is the largest at the bottom left etc.

Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts

Bond length, definitions of non-polar covalent bonds, polar covalent bonds and ionic bonds, lattice energy, bond energy, lewis structure, resonance structures, formal charge, naming of compounds

Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

VSEPR model, hybridization of orbitals, sigma bonding and pi bonding, molecular orbital model, bond order, paramagnetism

Chapter 5: stoichiometry
(Nothing new here)

Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry

Hydration of ions, strong, weak, non electrolytes, Molarity vs Molality, complete ionic equation, net ionic equation, Brønsted–Lowry definition of acids and bases, non-whole number oxidation numbers, electron donors and acceptors in redox reactions

Chapter 7: Chemical Energy

Heat, work, state function, extensive property, first law of thermodynamics, definition of internal energy, definition of enthalpy, constant-volume calorimetry

Chapter 8: Gases

Pressure, barometer, manometer, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Avogadro’s law, ideal gas law, standard temperature and pressure (STP), Dalton’s law of partial pressures, kinetic molecular theory, effusion and diffusion, real gases behavior, van der Waal’s equation, compressibility

Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

London dispersion forces, polarizability, capillary action, cohesive and adhesive forces, crystalline solids, amorphous solids, unit cell, x-ray diffraction analysis of solids, Bragg equation, atomic solids, metallic solids, network solids, Group 8A solids, molecular solids, ionic solids, hexagonal closest packed (hcp) structure, cubic closest packed (ccp) structure, simple cubic unit cell, body-centered unit cell, face-centered unit cell, net spheres, band model, substitutional alloy, interstitial alloy, doping, p-type semiconductor, n-type semiconductor, p-n junction, holes(semiconductor), octahedral and tetrahedral holes, vapor pressure, enthalpy of vaporization, enthalpy of fusion, definitions of melting and boiling, normal melting and boiling points, supercooling and superheating, phase diagram

----------

The above are primarily from the textbook, Chemistry: An Atoms First Approach, 2nd ed. which the course uses.

Chapter 1-4:
You really have to understand the concepts, read every single page in the notes and do all the review questions done in class. After you understand the concepts, you can definitely complete all the exam problems with ease.

For Chapter 7, the energy part uses some equations from thermodynamics (PHYS1112 have taught) so its quite easy too. Chapter 9 is just general gas laws stuff. For Chapter 5-9, reading every page is unnecessary, but do spend time on doing the review questions.

Professor Jia has a strong accent, but its actually easy to understand. His teaching is very good actually. He would make sure all of us understand those concepts before moving on. He would keep repeating some important points so we can be aware and remember it better.

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: Hard Midterm but Easy Final
reviews.comment_content:
The content mainly covers 9 chapters:
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2: Atomic Structure
Chapter 3: Chemical Bonding - General Concepts
Chapter 4: Chemical Bonding - Molecular Structures and Bonding Theories

Chapter 5: Chemical Stoichiometry
Chapter 6: Chemical Reactions in Aqueous Solution
Chapter 7: Chemical Energy
Chapter 8: Gases
Chapter 9: Solids and Liquids

The midterm covers the first 4 chapters while the final exam covers the latter 5 chapters.
Chapter 1 are easy as it is like a review of basic chemistry, especially if you have taken DSE Physics Elective 2 (Atomic physics), as it covers the atom models.
Chapter 2 is where the difficulty builds up, as you have to learn how to explain the behaviour of the atom species with the newly learnt atomic model.
Chapter 3 and 4 focus on atomic bonding, especially the covalent bonds, and as well as the atomic model version of the bonding theory.

For the latter 5 chapters, most contents are learnt in DSE Chemistry. For chapter 8, the general gas law is covered in DSE Physics.
Chapter 9 also contains some content that you may learn in CENG courses (Not sure, as I did not take CENG courses. I got this information from my friends.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The pronunciation of the professors makes this course the best course ever! ATOMS AtOmS aToMs (intended sarcasm)

*Coughs* *Coughs* To be serious, both professors provided some examples that are close to the exam format.
For Prof. Jia, his explanation of concepts is pretty much clear. He also provided a lot of examples and pictures for illustration. However, one problem is that the slides he uploaded on Canvas are incomplete at first, and upload the full version after the chapter is finished. This is not very good if we want to revise what we have learnt right after the lesson.
For Prof. Huang, she took a good approach to suggest some daily examples and its relationships in chemistry. She even made a demonstration for one of the inspirations (However, it is a demonstration of mixing bleach and alcohol, that has potential health risk. She even did the experiment WITHOUT any protective gears, despite she told us do not reproduce at home and she only mixed a small amount).

Final: 50%

reviews.comment_workload: There is no homework for this course. However, it is strongly recommended to do the exercises on the textbook and get familiar with the techniques to solve each question.

reviews.author: Ai
reviews.comment_content:
DSE Physics + DSE Chemistry + Some new concepts

Mid-term: (more difficult/involving concepts from DSE physics elective Atomic World)
Chapter 1.  Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2.   Atomic Structure and Periodicity
- (Most difficult) Use different models (e.g. Bohr model, Atomic orbitals) to view the structure of atoms.
- Write electron configurations.
- Analyse variations of different properties across the periodic table.
Chapter 3.   Bonding: General Concepts
- Ionic bonds and covalent bonds
- Draw Lewis Structures (~structures of molecules)
- Properties of covalent bonds and structures (polarity)
Chapter 4.   Molecular structure and Bonding Theories
- Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory (~shape of molecules/geometry of the structures/angles between bonds)
- Valence Bond Theory (about how bonds are formed in the orbital model ~Hybridization of orbitals/sigma bond & pi bond)

Final: (Similar to DSE Chemistry)
Chapter 5.  Chemical Stoichiometry
- Stoichiometry = Calculation/quantitative analysis
- Calculate number of moles, mass, molar mass, percentage yield, etc.
Chapter 6.  Chemical reactions in aqueous solution
- Precipitation
- Acid-base reactions
- Redox reactions
Chapter 7.  Thermochemistry: Chemical Energy
- Energy (E = Q + W)
- Hess's Law
- Standard enthalpy of formation/reaction
- Present/new energy sources
Chapter 8.  Gases
- Ideal gas law
- pV=nRT
- Dalton's law of partial pressure
- Kinetic molecular theory of gases (frequency of collision/vigorous collision)
- Real gases
Chapter 9.  Liquids and solids
- Intermolecular forces (VDWF/H-bond, etc.)
- Properties of Liquid
- Phase Diagrams (changing states)
- Solids: structures of ionic/molecular/non-crystalline solids
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very nice!
The professors and lectures were nice. There were review questions to review previous concepts every lecture. They would also stay to answer questions from Zoom chatroom after class.
The TA was really good. She replied to emails very efficiently. She held optional but helpful tutorials before mid-term and final exams.
The assessment was very transparent. They published statistics, like mean and S.D., and set up paper checking sessions. We could know where we got wrong and what the correct answers are. This helped us learn better by reviewing and allowed discussion after exams. (Some classmates argued about two questions. The professor accepted their reasons and gave them marks.) Plus, they worked efficiently. It was my last final exam but the first one to finish paper checking and release the grade.

It is just that you may feel a little frustrated if you expect very good pronunciation in lectures.

reviews.comment_workload:
Only mid-term and final exams 50% each (100 Chemistry MCs throughout the whole semester) (for online mode this semester). 2 lectures each week. No attendance required.

Understanding the materials thoroughly should be enough. Before mid-term, the orbital model may require some time to understand. You need to accept the concept that electrons are wave. After mid-term, it is nearly all about DSE Chemistry with a few new concepts.

They suggested optional homework questions from the textbook, and said 20% of the exam questions were similar to the homework ones. You can work on them after each chapter or when preparing for the exams if you have time. They would publish the model answer.

reviews.comment_teaching:
JIA, Guocheng is responsible for the first half of the course(Ch. 1-4). Although his accent is bad and sometimes I can't understand the questions, he gave lots of exercises for us to do within lessons (by polling) after finishing each sub-topics. Also some review questions at the beginning of every lecture. He will explain deeply if the accuracy is below 50%. I love the way he teaches because I seldom study and this helps me refresh my memory.

no graded assignment for this sem, low-pressure course. All you need to do to achieve a range is to do the practice questions in the textbook that prof. assigned every chapter(around 20-30 for ch.1-4, 10-15 for ch.5-9) because 20% of the questions will be covered in both exams.

Honestly, if you did study hard in high school chemistry, you only have to do revision for 30mins every week to attain an A-range grade. Also, try your best to answer the review questions so as to consolidate the knowledge.

For me, I got lv5 in HKDSE Chemistry and I only study for 3-4hrs before every exam and finally got A-.

reviews.comment_content:
Midterm:
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Chapter 4 : Molecular Structure and Orbitals

Final:
Chapter 5:  Stoichiometry
Chapter 6 : Types of Chemical Reactions
Chapter 7 : Chemical energy
Chapter 8: Gases
Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

The content in midterm includes the basic knowledge of atoms and molecules but not like the things you have learned from the high school, basically you have to learn everything AGAIN.
The content in the final exam includes the change of molecules and the assembly of molecules , they are mainly calculations so good luck to those who are mediocre in math. Both midterm and final are consist of 50 MC questions and 20% of the questions will be directly copied from the assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr Li has a strong and loud voice and you may feel quite uncomfortable when taking his first lesson, but you will eventually realize the voice of this "Mad Man" can make you focus in the lesson. Moreover, his lecture ppts are detailed and well-organized.

Mr Jia looks like a humble and shy man, his voice is so soft that you may automatically fall asleep . You can't really concentrate in the lesson whether you are interested in Chemistry or not. His lecture ppts are simple and straight forward  , you can flip through these ppts quickly for revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (50%) : 64/100 ( Mean 59.63; SD 17.23; Highest 98; Median 58)

Final (50%) : 68/100   (Mean 66.28; SD 16.26; Highest 100; Median 68)

Overall
Mean 63.5 SD 15.1 highest 98 Median 62

You can see that my scores in both midterm and final are slightly higher than the mean, I get a B grade after all. If you are aiming for A range , ~ 1.0 SD above mean is needed.
reviews.comment_workload:
Absolutely depends on the time you spent on this course.  I highly recommend each of you to finish all the assignments in each chapter since it can test whether you are familiar with the topic or not , and you will gain some free score if you are able to memorize all the questions and the answers of the assignment simultaneously. (But seriously, it is impossible to memorize all of them)

Last but not least, this foundation course can help you realize whether Chemistry is your preferred major or not. If you think you don't like these content at all , just pick  another  since Chemistry is definitely not your " True Love" .

reviews.author: couch_potato
reviews.title: Excellent course planning with impressive lecturer
reviews.comment_content:
This course has been modified to a 3-credit course.
Overall, this is a well-planned curriculum, with the professor progressing from structures, theories and properties of atoms, bonding, molecules, and finally linking them to macroscopic understanding of the chemistry as we understand it. It really helps to fill in the atomic orbital theory, a very important part of chemistry that is completely cut from the HKDSE syllabus.
The professor highly recommends the book "Chemistry: An Atom's First Approach, 2e".

Below is the list of chapters:
1. Chemical Foundations
2. Atomic Structure and Periodicity
3. Bonding - General Concepts
4. Molecular Structures and Orbitals
5. Stoichiometry
6. Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry
7. Chemical Energy
8. Gases
9. Liquids and Solids

Some might describe this course as more similar to a quantum physics course.

It is highly recommended that Chapter 8 Gases is studied in conjunction with thermodynamics in PHYS1112, since studying them together can help reinforce the understanding of the concepts in the chapter.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Li Xiaoyuan is a very impressive teacher.
His charisma and his unusually loud and accented voice combined makes him one of the most adorable and attention-grabbing lecturers. Or more accurately, master of his Talk Show!!
His lecture notes actually contain more details than the textbook that he repeatedly recommends during class, and while it is possible to be confused during lectures, he does an excellent job clarifying confusing concepts face to face.
Personally I really like this lecturer, and hope you guys can be taught by him!

reviews.comment_workload: There are no quizzes, homework or projects for this course. For local students, almost all the workload goes into studying atomic orbitals before mid-terms as well as Chapter 9 before finals, and Chapter 8 if you have not taken PHYS1112, since they are totally cut from the HKDSE syllabus. Preparation using Advanced Placement materials is personally recommended.

reviews.author: ettk
reviews.title: More like a self-learning course
reviews.comment_content: I prefer not to repeat what others have mentioned. Topics are essentially the same, with orbitals being the core of the whole course. The focus should always be put on this part. In terms of difficulty, I believe it is reasonable for an introductory course to university chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Li has only 2 one-hour lectures per week, which he always claimed it is insufficient for him to cover all materials. Instead of focusing on the most difficult parts, he chose to keep on repeating topics that are "important" yet should be understood by most simply by reading the textbook. He seemed to be not so good at time management as he always overrun his lectures, and eventually cut off one topic from the syllabus due to time shortfall.
reviews.comment_grading: I guess the standard university grading guideline was adopted. People complained about the poor grades received after the release of grades as usual for science courses. As for grading scheme, simply the average of your midterm and final score.
reviews.comment_workload: Many complained it was too much for a 2-credit course. I think it is rather reasonable though. The only difference between Prof Li's CHEM1020 and probably the rest of your courses is that he expects everyone to read through the chapter before he starts one, which I believe not many people have time to do so in UST. As long as you follow his instructions in reading the textbook chapters, you will find it fine to follow his lectures.

reviews.author: chorongie
reviews.title: Grading not bad, IA save the whole course
reviews.comment_content: The session from the first lecturer is much more difficult. The part from the second lecturer is much easier as they are things similar to DSE Chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are not that useful to be honest, but reading through the lectures will helps you get a better understanding and probably higher grades. The important part of the course is actually the tutorials hold by IA. It is very useful to the midterms and final as it includes the most related content for the test and final. I think it will be even better if you read through and understand the lectures first before the tutorials since you can ask about contents you dont understand and the IA is actually explaining it better and she will tell you it is not tested in the test or exam if the content you asked is not related. And i would highly recommend to attend the tutorials a few times especially if you are not familiar with the things taught. The 2 tutorials are held before midterm and final respectively and each tutorials will have 5 sessions to choose and the contents of each sessions are the same.

reviews.author: XXM
reviews.comment_content:
Before MT (Prof. HALPERT)

reviews.comment_teaching:
No lecture video provided.

The comments towards Prof. HALPERT's teaching are really controversial. Personally I feel his classes are well-prepared, and it is always quite comfortable to have a native speaker as instructor for this kind of courses.
He suggested us to go through the textbook after each class, but I personally think it will be more effective if you only do it with the parts that you don't fully understand.
Also, personally I think the professor dug WAY TOO DEEP into the quantum parts, which I suspect is because of his own interest of research.

Prof. HUANG is also friendly and helpful. Someone complains that she only read the PPT. But I occasionally sit in the front of the LT and see her own notes for teaching. I bet it is much more elaborate than most of the students. In addition, she designed experiments to add some fun to the class, some of which are quite interesting.

Ms. Tse Kiu Lee is the best IA I have ever had.
Ms. Tse Kiu Lee is the best IA I have ever had.
Ms. Tse Kiu Lee is the best IA I have ever had.
I highly recommend everyone to attend her tutorials.
And she is always more than willing to help us with all kinds of issue, whether about the knowledge itself or the controversy caused by the annoying “X of the above”.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know about other CHEM courses but according to what my friends told me. The grading is similar to last semester by Prof. JIA.

The grading scheme is as follow:
Assessment:
Assignments (2)    10%  
mean: 50.6/60 & 37.7/40
Midterm Exam       40%
mean: 52.5/90  SD: 13.2  High: 90
Final Exam            50%     
(Non-cumulative)
mean: 78.4/90  SD: 11.2 High: 100

My scores for reference:
Assignments: 56/60 & 40/40
Midterm: 81/90
Final: 96/100
Grade: A+

The format of the exam is quite annoying though.
You should expect to face things like:
Which of the following is true/false

E two of them
F three of them
G all of the above
H none of the above
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments are not very demanding.
But the given answers of the review homework before MT contradicted with each others. This cost me a lot of time to make thing clear to myself.

reviews.author: Jacky 01
reviews.comment_content: At the beginning the topic is about bonding and s,p,d orbit, the topic is about quantum mechanics and the concept is quite hard to understand. But once you understand the concept it will be very easy.  There is not a lot of things to calculate, we just need to arrange the electron of the atom. After the mid-term, the content is mainly DSE chemistry and some physics topic such as enthalpy change, redox reaction, precipitation reaction and ideal gas law. The only new topic after the mid-term is the real gas equation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring, it is mainly ppt reading. But after the mid-term we can see some chemistry experiment done by instructor, some of the experiment are quite fun. The tutorial however is very useful. There are 2 optional tutorial class before the mid-term and final exam. The tutorial class covered the most important content of the topic. If you are very familiar with the tutorial notes, you can at least won't below mean.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ok grade. 50% final exam, 40% mid-term, 10% homework.There will be 2 homework which is quite easy. The topic covered in the mid-term will not covered by final exam. As the new topic is covered mainly in the mid-term, final exam is way easier than mid-term. Final exam and mid-term consist of MC and long question. The MC is quite hard as some of the question have too many choice, such as: which of the following statement is true/false
A ......
B ......
C ......
D ......
E two of them
F three of them
G all of them
H none of them
There are quite a lot of this kind of question, you must be very familiar with the topic and confident about the answer in order to get the true answer. So personally I think MC is harder than long question. You should do the sample paper and self-practice in order to do revision.
mid-term 53.5/90 mean 51/90
final exam 79/100 mean 76.9
assignment 1 54.5/60
assignment 2 40/40
final grade B
reviews.comment_workload: Light work load. Only 2 assignment. Plus the final exam won't cover the topic of mid-term, it is quite easy to do revision.

reviews.author: Jonathan:-)
reviews.title: Fair course content& instructor.
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1  Introduction: Matter and Measurements
Chapter 2  Chemical Foundations
-Be discussed in the first 1.5 weeks & no lecture videos provided-
Chapter 3  Atomic Structure and Periodicity(~4 weeks)
--------------1st assignment---------------
Chapter 4  Bonding: General Concepts(~1.5 weeks)
Chapter 5  Molecular Geometry and Bonding Theories(~3 weeks)
--Midterm covers till 5.1 and 2nd assignment covers Chapter 5---
Chapter 6  Chemical Stoichiometry
Chapter 7   Chemical reactions in aqueous solution
Chapter 8   Thermochemistry: Chemical Energy
Chapter 9  Gases
-------NON-CUMULATIVE final--------------

Chapter 1 2 6 7 8 9 are very easy, however, you still need to spend some time on the concepts in order not to make any careless mistakes.

Chapter 3~5 are somewhat hard to digest and you need to spend some time to understand the theories behind.

I would say the contents are not well-organized. They are kind of messy, though most of them are useful to future chem study.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His English accent is a bit hard to understand but you can manage to get used to it after a short while.

He mainly reads the PowerPoint, and some supplement may be added from time to time, which may be useful.

The PPT's are well-prepared. Also the lecture videos will be provided, so you don't necessarily need to attend the lecture.

My suggestion is that you only need to attend the first 2 lectures, the 2 lectures before midterm (because the lecture videos may not be uploaded immediately).
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say it's very good.

Assignment 1 5%
Assignment 2 5%
Mid term         40%
Final exam 50%

mean for total score is ~63%, which gives ~B/B-
~79% gives an A-
~92% gives an A+

ONE NOTE: DO WATCH THE LECTURE VIDEOS BEFORE BOTH EXAMS because he will delete some PPT posted on canvas, some of which are outstandingly useful.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. It's more like a half credit-bearing course.

reviews.title: Not too bad, considering you don't have a choice whether or not to take this course.
reviews.comment_content:
There are a total of 9 topics in this course.
1. Matter and Measurement
2. Chemical Foundations
3. Atomic Orbital
4. Chemical Bonding
5. VSEPR
6. Molecular Orbital
7. Balancing equations, molar mass, etc.
8. Thermodynamics
9. Ideal gas (And a little bit of real gas)

Most of the topics have been taught during your time in secondary school, so they are not so big of a deal.

However, pay attention to Atomic orbital and molecular orbital.
They are quite hard for someone who has never been exposed to quantum mechanics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jia's teaching is actually not too bad if you set aside his most peculiar accent.
He is patient and more than willing to answer your questions after lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid Term:
Mean - 50
SD - 15.1
Max. - 89.5 out of 90
Min. - 16.5 out of 90

Final:
Mean - 66
SD - 16.2
Max. - 97 out of 100
Min. - 21.5 out of 100

Do try to finish the sample papers before exams, especially the MC questions. Jia's MCs tend to be very tricky, and sometimes he even uses Engineering Psychology to mislead you.
i.e. He uses words like "By definition","No doubt" or "exactly" that conveys certainty on choices that are wrong,
and words that convey uncertainty like "might", "maybe" or "there is a chance" on answers that are correct.

I didn't do the sample paper for midterm, I got 65%
I did the sample paper for final, I got 92%

Seriously, DO the SAMPLE PAPER, especially the MCs.
reviews.comment_workload:

As for the 2 assignments, there is no reason for why you cannot get full marks on both of them. They are really easy.

reviews.author: FKLFKL
reviews.title: Low work load but please study hard for mid term final
reviews.comment_content:
This course is about some basics of atoms, ranging from old theories to modern atomic models.
The first chapter is easy and manageable if your chemistry grades were satisfactory in high school.
But things taught in chapter two will probably different from your perception of atoms and so you have to forget most of the things about atoms structure taught in high school before you study this chapter.
Things that taught in the chapters later are closely related to chapter 2 (e.g. molecular orbitals), so make sure you study chapter 2 well.
Overall, the amount of content taught is reasonable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair. Although professor talked in a lively way, but most of his words were just from the power point (and as the time for the class commence is 10:30 a.m., many students including me fell asleep), and before mid-term and final exams, he may or may not finish teaching the content covered in the exams. But if he cannot finish the things covered in the exams , he would still test you about the things he didn't talk about, just because "They're included in the reading assignments! Lectures are conducted to help you understand the things in the book." So please be careful.

reviews.author: cccy
reviews.comment_content:
The course focused on teaching fundamental chemistry knowledge.
There were 9 chapters in total.

Matter and Measurement
Chemical Foundations
Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Bonding I : General Concepts
Bonding II: Molecular Geometry and Bonding Theories
Chemical Stiochiometry
Reactions in Aqueous Solution
Thermochemistry: Chemical Energy
Gases

Lecture videos were posted on Canvas.
Lecture notes were posted before the lesson. The answers of the notes were posted after the chapter ended.

Textbook: "Chemistry: An Atoms First Approach" Zumdahl and Zumdahl, 2016 Cengage Learning International Edition

It was not required to purchase.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Jia exerted himself in teaching this course. Yet, his pronunciation and intonation have large room for improvement. It is quite difficult to listen and follow.  Besides, he did attempt not to dictate the words that were typed on the PowerPoint but finally he failed to do so.

There were two tutorial lessons, before the mid-term exam and before the final exam, which were not compulsory. The IA extracted the main points and taught them again.

Both Prof Jia and IA are very helpful in deed. If you have any questions, you can ask them in class or via email. They will respond to questions within one to two days, or even shorter.
reviews.comment_grading: If you work hard, you can achieve good results. You have to understand the concepts thoroughly for the sake of answering the MC questions correctly. Students usually answered the short questions almost correctly but they failed to answer the MC questions correctly.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was not heavy. Two assignments were required to hand in. Besides, there were several pieces of homework, which were given for the preparation of exams.

Assessment and Grading
Assignments (x2) 10%
Midterm Exam 40%
Final Exam 50%
All Exams were closed-book.

reviews.comment_content: Atomic structure, orbitals and bonding theory, molecular geometry, gas laws, properties of solids and liquids, chemical kinetics. Those are really helpful for understanding concepts and seeing if you're missing stuffs required for exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very slow and unclear teaching. Prof is too self-aware to essentially give you any damn. Also speaks too softly and too muffled. Not gonna take attendance so tbh no loss skipping lessons (especially if you have one or two friends who insist on attending all lessons). Also pronunciation -- abandon all hope of trying to understanding everything prof says. Siginificant figures and oshun (oxygen) are all you're gonna get.
reviews.comment_grading: Not the most lenient but still really good. If you've gone through the stuffs thoroughly then it shouldn't be a problem at all. Remember to do the homework (no need to hand-in -- they have the answers posted). Exams consist of MCs (up to 8 choices I remember) and LQs. The time for examinations are very long and to an extent, excessive. Most of us had at least 20 minutes remaining after checking twice. Good idea to leave early since your mistakes are mostly gonna be careless ones and YOU'RE NOT. GONNA. NOTICE. THEM. Deal with it.  Just mind the significant figures and A range shouldn't be difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Not the lightest but still very light. 2 assignments, and midterm + final. Assignments are in exam formats so very good for practice actually. Just remember to hand in on time and it'll be fine usually.
