reviews.author: Edward Pham
reviews.title: Short review
reviews.comment_content:
There is no attendance requirement for this course. The exam syllabus is the same as last semesters. Check out other reviews for that. The following are the new concepts this course teaches:

Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Laws – law of definite proportion, law of multiple proportions
Older atomic models – billiard ball model, plum-pudding model, Rutherford model, bohr’s model
Experiments – cathode ray tube experiment, millikan oil droplet experiment

Chapter 2: Atomic Structures and Periodicity

The first part consists of chapters 1 and 2 of DSE E2 physics.

Second part is about quantum atomic model:

Schrodinger’s equation, wave function, atomic orbital, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, quantum numbers, Aufbau principle

The chapter also teaches how to use QM model to account for trends in the periodic table, for instance, why electronegativity is highest at the top right, why atomic size is the largest at the bottom left etc.

Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts

Bond length, definitions of non-polar covalent bonds, polar covalent bonds and ionic bonds, lattice energy, bond energy, lewis structure, resonance structures, formal charge, naming of compounds

Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

VSEPR model, hybridization of orbitals, sigma bonding and pi bonding, molecular orbital model, bond order, paramagnetism

Chapter 5: stoichiometry
(Nothing new here)

Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry

Hydration of ions, strong, weak, non electrolytes, Molarity vs Molality, complete ionic equation, net ionic equation, Brønsted–Lowry definition of acids and bases, non-whole number oxidation numbers, electron donors and acceptors in redox reactions

Chapter 7: Chemical Energy

Heat, work, state function, extensive property, first law of thermodynamics, definition of internal energy, definition of enthalpy, constant-volume calorimetry

Chapter 8: Gases

Pressure, barometer, manometer, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Avogadro’s law, ideal gas law, standard temperature and pressure (STP), Dalton’s law of partial pressures, kinetic molecular theory, effusion and diffusion, real gases behavior, van der Waal’s equation, compressibility

Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

London dispersion forces, polarizability, capillary action, cohesive and adhesive forces, crystalline solids, amorphous solids, unit cell, x-ray diffraction analysis of solids, Bragg equation, atomic solids, metallic solids, network solids, Group 8A solids, molecular solids, ionic solids, hexagonal closest packed (hcp) structure, cubic closest packed (ccp) structure, simple cubic unit cell, body-centered unit cell, face-centered unit cell, net spheres, band model, substitutional alloy, interstitial alloy, doping, p-type semiconductor, n-type semiconductor, p-n junction, holes(semiconductor), octahedral and tetrahedral holes, vapor pressure, enthalpy of vaporization, enthalpy of fusion, definitions of melting and boiling, normal melting and boiling points, supercooling and superheating, phase diagram

----------

The above are primarily from the textbook, Chemistry: An Atoms First Approach, 2nd ed. which the course uses.

And I probably haven't included things from the lecture notes, Professor Li's lecture notes are so full of content, which deterred me from reading them.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor JIA, Guocheng was responsible for the mid-term exam content. He spoke quite softly but he tried to illustrate examples for better understanding. As the content is new to me, I spent much time listening to his lecture, but later discovered that self-studying could also do the job.

Professor LI, Xiaoyuan was responsible for the final exam content. His lecture slides have highlighted many key points, and also included some extra information. The professor was very passionate and knowledgeable. However, I did not attend much of his lectures as the content is pretty easy.

The teaching assistant hosted two tutorials, one before each exam. She would briefly summarise the content covered in the exams and offer some sample questions as exercise. Even though the number of questions is quite little, they are still helpful for you to test your understanding and to familiarize with the exam format.

reviews.author: Gary Gao
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Laws – law of definite proportion, law of multiple proportions
Older atomic models – billiard ball model, plum-pudding model, Rutherford model, bohr’s model
Experiments – cathode ray tube experiment, millikan oil droplet experiment

Chapter 2: Atomic Structures and Periodicity

The first part consists of chapters 1 and 2 of DSE E2 physics.

Second part is about quantum atomic model:

Schrodinger’s equation, wave function, atomic orbital, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, quantum numbers, Aufbau principle

The chapter also teaches how to use QM model to account for trends in the periodic table, for instance, why electronegativity is highest at the top right, why atomic size is the largest at the bottom left etc.

Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts

Bond length, definitions of non-polar covalent bonds, polar covalent bonds and ionic bonds, lattice energy, bond energy, lewis structure, resonance structures, formal charge, naming of compounds

Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

VSEPR model, hybridization of orbitals, sigma bonding and pi bonding, molecular orbital model, bond order, paramagnetism

Chapter 5: stoichiometry
(Nothing new here)

Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry

Hydration of ions, strong, weak, non electrolytes, Molarity vs Molality, complete ionic equation, net ionic equation, Brønsted–Lowry definition of acids and bases, non-whole number oxidation numbers, electron donors and acceptors in redox reactions

Chapter 7: Chemical Energy

Heat, work, state function, extensive property, first law of thermodynamics, definition of internal energy, definition of enthalpy, constant-volume calorimetry

Chapter 8: Gases

Pressure, barometer, manometer, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Avogadro’s law, ideal gas law, standard temperature and pressure (STP), Dalton’s law of partial pressures, kinetic molecular theory, effusion and diffusion, real gases behavior, van der Waal’s equation, compressibility

Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

London dispersion forces, polarizability, capillary action, cohesive and adhesive forces, crystalline solids, amorphous solids, unit cell, x-ray diffraction analysis of solids, Bragg equation, atomic solids, metallic solids, network solids, Group 8A solids, molecular solids, ionic solids, hexagonal closest packed (hcp) structure, cubic closest packed (ccp) structure, simple cubic unit cell, body-centered unit cell, face-centered unit cell, net spheres, band model, substitutional alloy, interstitial alloy, doping, p-type semiconductor, n-type semiconductor, p-n junction, holes(semiconductor), octahedral and tetrahedral holes, vapor pressure, enthalpy of vaporization, enthalpy of fusion, definitions of melting and boiling, normal melting and boiling points, supercooling and superheating, phase diagram
reviews.comment_grading: You will get very good grades if you review the concepts frequently.

reviews.title: Just skip lectures and self study if you can't understand his English.
reviews.comment_content:
TL;DR: Be prepared to be amazed by incomplete slides and countless shapes and diagrams that you never saw in Secondary School Chemistry lessons or books.

Prof. Jia taught chapters 1-4 for this semester, all are covered in the midterm.

Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations
Chapter 2: Atomic Structure and Periodicity
Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts
Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

Almost half of the content is outside of the scope of Secondary School Chemistry.

Lecture Slides posted on Canvas are incomplete and the completed version will only be posted after the end of the chapter.

However, Prof Jia only posted the complete slides days before the mid-term.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TL;DR again: In case of terrible English, keep calm and skip lectures.

Expect a very heavy accent and unclear English in the face-to-face lectures, and inaudible English in Zoom meetings/recordings.

If you cannot understand his English, skip lectures and self-study. Internet sources are more reliable and easier to understand.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main source of workload is self-learning. Be prepared to learn chapters 1-4 by yourself if you can't understand his English. (I self-studied chapters 2-4 within a month. It was terrible.)

No homework for this lecture.

Before the mid-term exam and final exam, the IA will give us a tutorial session which is extremely useful. She will also explain the questions with a high wrong ratio after each exam. In final exam, Professor Li gave us a review session for refreshing our concepts and highlight some important concepts.

All lectures are recorded so you can learn with your own speed.

reviews.comment_grading:
50% midterm,50% of final.
The midterm is open-book and online. There are 50 questions and each worth 2 points. You have 2 hours to finish the exam. Since it is open-booked, it shall not be too difficult, and there are plenty of time for you to search. The only thing you need to do is to attend the tutorial before the exam and finish all the problem given by the TA. I get 86/100, 1.34sd above the mean.
The Final consists of 2 sessions. There is a break in between. Both of them are consists of MC questions only. I only gets a mean for the first session and do quite well in the 2nd session. I am above 1.0x sd.
I get an A, while I expect an A- because I mess up the final. So the grading is quite good
reviews.comment_workload: There is optional homework for you to finish. The homework won't be graded, yet 20% of the exam question are from the homework. I suggest you to finish at least some of them, if not all.

reviews.author: jimmyleung
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term:
Classification of matter, Elements and Periodic table, Measurements and significant figures, atoms, ions, molecules, compounds, Atomic spectra and the Bohr model, Quantum mechanical model(Wave-particle duality, Quantum numbers, energy and shapes of atomic orbitals, polyelectronic atoms), Periodic trends in atomic properties, Ionic bonding, Covalent bonding, Lewis Structures(Resonance, Formal Charges), VSEPR

After mid-term:
Valence Bond Theory and hybridization, Molecular Orbital Theory, Chemical stiochiometry, Reactions in aqueous solutions(Properties, precipitation, acid-base, redox), Chemical energy(1st law of thermodynamics, enthalpy, Hess' Law), Gases(Properties, gas laws, Kinetic Molecular Theory, Ideal and real gases)

More than half of the course are used to teach Bohr model, Quantum mechanical model, Lewis Structures, VSEPR Theory, Valence Bond Theory and Molecular Orbital Theory. They are the most important content in this course(and in Chemistry).

The best way to do this course is by forming a study group with ppl who did physics in high school and ask them questions like crazily. Or else except you're very clever or hard-working, you'll fk it up very hard.
I actually think that there should also be an honour course for chemistry, cuz one semester for all these contents for a normal local student is really too much.

Course content (copied from other reviews)
Chapter 1: Chemical Foundations

Laws – law of definite proportion, the law of multiple proportions
Older atomic models – billiard ball model, plum-pudding model, Rutherford model, Bohr's model
Experiments – cathode ray tube experiment, Millikan oil droplet experiment

Chapter 2: Atomic Structures and Periodicity

The first part consists of chapters 1 and 2 of DSE E2 physics.

Second part is about quantum atomic model:

Schrodinger’s equation, wave function, atomic orbital, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, quantum numbers, Aufbau principle

The chapter also teaches how to use QM model to account for trends in the periodic table, for instance, why electronegativity is highest at the top right, why atomic size is the largest at the bottom left etc.

Chapter 3: Bonding: General Concepts

Bond length, definitions of non-polar covalent bonds, polar covalent bonds and ionic bonds, lattice energy, bond energy, lewis structure, resonance structures, formal charge, naming of compounds

Chapter 4: Molecular Structure and Orbitals

VSEPR model, hybridization of orbitals, sigma bonding and pi bonding, molecular orbital model, bond order, paramagnetism

Chapter 5: stoichiometry
(Nothing new here)

Chapter 6: Types of Chemical Reactions and Solution Stoichiometry

Hydration of ions, strong, weak, non-electrolytes, Molarity vs Molality, complete ionic equation, net ionic equation, Brønsted–Lowry definition of acids and bases, non-whole number oxidation numbers, electron donors and acceptors in redox reactions

Chapter 7: Chemical Energy

Heat, work, state function, extensive property, the first law of thermodynamics, the definition of internal energy, the definition of enthalpy, constant-volume calorimetry

Chapter 8: Gases

Pressure, barometer, manometer, Boyle’s law, Charles’s law, Avogadro’s law, ideal gas law, standard temperature and pressure (STP), Dalton’s law of partial pressures, kinetic molecular theory, effusion and diffusion, real gases behaviour, van der Waal’s equation, compressibility

Chapter 9: Liquids and Solids

London dispersion forces, polarizability, capillary action, cohesive and adhesive forces, crystalline solids, amorphous solids, unit cell, x-ray diffraction analysis of solids, Bragg equation, atomic solids, metallic solids, network solids, Group 8A solids, molecular solids, ionic solids, hexagonal closest packed (hcp) structure, cubic closest packed (ccp) structure, simple cubic unit cell, body-centred unit cell, face-centred unit cell, net spheres, band model, substitutional alloy, interstitial alloy, doping, p-type semiconductor, n-type semiconductor, p-n junction, holes(semiconductor), octahedral and tetrahedral holes, vapour pressure, enthalpy of vaporization, enthalpy of fusion, definitions of melting and boiling, normal melting and boiling points, supercooling and superheating, phase diagram
reviews.comment_teaching:
The English of Prof Jia is hell, it's more like Thai rather than English. Prof Li is better in pronunciation, which makes the lectures a little bit attractive. However, both of them just read the ppt out so not attending lectures and read the ppt by yourself has no big difference.
TA Elaine is angle btw.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair, A range is very big I heard ppl getting A for an overall 80%. Cannot find the distribution graph but I remember that the score is quite normally distributed.
For the final grade, it counts 50% mt and final, mt asks ch1-4, and 5-9 is for final.
Score:
MT:
Mean: 66.35/ 100
SD: 14.68
Median: 66/ 100

Final:
Mean: 63.06/ 100
SD: 14.06
Median: 62/ 100

My score: 94（+1.9sd） for mt and 88(+1.6sd) for final, overall 91/100, got an A+. The cut off for A+ is probably 90.
I got 5** in physics(E2E3) and 5* in chemistry so the grade is fair for me.
Reach out for help from dailos in wtapp group, they're more than willing to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is zero for me as I have learnt all the content before. However, base on my observations and the frequency of others asking questions, it's probably quite chur for normal ppl. Read the lecture notes and slowly digest the context. Don't be hesitate to ask questions cuz if you didn't do physics in high school, the concepts will be very abstract for you.
